title: Investigative Task: Understanding Normal Distribution
driving_question: How can we use the concept of normal distribution to understand and predict the amount of gold applied to a necklace during production?
short_background_context: The College Board's AP Statistics exam includes an investigative task that requires students to understand and apply statistical concepts in real-world scenarios. One such task involves the production of gold necklaces. A machine applies a certain amount of gold to each necklace it produces, and this amount can be modeled using a normal distribution. The mean amount of gold applied is 300mg, with a standard deviation of 5mg. This task will guide you through understanding and applying this distribution to predict the likelihood of a necklace containing a certain amount of gold.
tasks: Task 1: Graphically represent the normal distribution of the amount of gold applied to the necklaces. Include the mean and standard deviation on your graph.
Task 2: Using the 'normalcdf' function, calculate the probability of a necklace containing between 296mg and 304mg of gold.
Task 3: Provide a written explanation of your findings, including how you used the normal distribution and 'normalcdf' function to calculate the probability.
pre_thinking_prompts: What does a normal distribution graph look like?
What do the mean and standard deviation represent in this context?
How can we use the 'normalcdf' function to calculate probabilities?
reflection_prompt: Reflect on your understanding of normal distribution and how it can be applied in real-world scenarios. How confident do you feel in your ability to calculate probabilities using this distribution?
ai_tutor_prompts: What does the mean of 300mg represent in this context?
Why is the standard deviation important in understanding the distribution?
Can you explain how the 'normalcdf' function works?
remix_zone: Students could remix this problem by considering different means and standard deviations, or by applying the concept to different real-world scenarios, such as the production of other types of jewelry or goods.
